Figure captions
Figure 1.

first_author: Non-metric multidimensional scaling (NMDS) ordinations of vegetation plots for four strata: (A) trees
raw: Non-metric multidimensional scaling (NMDS) ordinations of vegetation plots for four strata: (A) trees, (B) shrubs, (C) herbs and (D) regeneration. Points represent sample plots coloured by forest type; polygons delineate convex hulls for each forest type. Red arrows indicate fitted environmental vectors significant at p < 0.05 based on 999 permutations. Stress values are shown for each ordination.
Figure 2.

first_author: Alpha-diversity metrics across vegetation strata. Panels show (A) species richness
raw: Alpha-diversity metrics across vegetation strata. Panels show (A) species richness, (B) Shannon diversity (H′), (C) Simpson diversity (1 – D) and (D) Pielou’s evenness (J). Boxplots depict medians and interquartile ranges; points represent individual plots.
Figure 3.

first_author: Sample-based species accumulation curves for herbs
raw: Sample-based species accumulation curves for herbs, regeneration, shrubs and trees. Solid lines indicate mean richness across random permutations; shaded envelopes show 95% confidence intervals.
Figure 4.

first_author: Canonical correspondence analysis (CCA) biplots for (A) trees
raw: Canonical correspondence analysis (CCA) biplots for (A) trees, (B) shrubs, (C) herbs and (D) regeneration. Points represent plots and arrows denote environmental predictors retained after variance inflation factor screening (threshold = 10). Arrow length indicates the strength of correlations with ordination axes.
Figure 5.

first_author: Random-forest variable-importance ranking for predictors of regeneration richness. Bars show percentage increase in mean squared error (%IncMSE) following permutation of each variable during five-fold cross-validation. Higher values indicate stronger influence on predictive accuracy.
raw: Random-forest variable-importance ranking for predictors of regeneration richness. Bars show percentage increase in mean squared error (%IncMSE) following permutation of each variable during five-fold cross-validation. Higher values indicate stronger influence on predictive accuracy.
Figure 6.

first_author: Variation in plot-level species richness along the elevational gradient for herbs
raw: Variation in plot-level species richness along the elevational gradient for herbs, regeneration, shrubs and trees. Curves represent locally weighted regression fits with 95% confidence bands.
Table captions
Table 2.

first_author: Results of permutational multivariate analysis of variance (PERMANOVA) and tests of multivariate dispersion for vegetation strata across forest types. p-values are based on 999 permutations.
raw: Results of permutational multivariate analysis of variance (PERMANOVA) and tests of multivariate dispersion for vegetation strata across forest types. p-values are based on 999 permutations.
Table 3.

first_author: Summary of canonical correspondence analyses by vegetation stratum. Environmental variables were selected following iterative variance inflation factor screening (threshold = 10). Significance of constrained inertia was assessed using 999 permutations.
raw: Summary of canonical correspondence analyses by vegetation stratum. Environmental variables were selected following iterative variance inflation factor screening (threshold = 10). Significance of constrained inertia was assessed using 999 permutations.
Table 4.

first_author: Mean alpha-diversity metrics by vegetation stratum. Values are mean ± standard deviation.
raw: Mean alpha-diversity metrics by vegetation stratum. Values are mean ± standard deviation.
Table 5.

first_author: Summary of indicator-species analysis by stratum. Groups were defined by elevational class (low
raw: Summary of indicator-species analysis by stratum. Groups were defined by elevational class (low, mid and high). Significance was assessed using 999 permutations at α = 0.05.
Table 6.

first_author: Cross-validated performance of machine-learning models predicting regeneration richness across five folds. R² denotes coefficient of determination; RMSE
raw: Cross-validated performance of machine-learning models predicting regeneration richness across five folds. R² denotes coefficient of determination; RMSE, root mean square error; MAE, mean absolute error. Full fold-level output is provided in Appendix S7.
